prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong in this situation. The scenario is about splitting bills with their girlfriend. The author pays all the bills because their girlfriend works part-time, but after an incident where the girlfriend had to pay for takeout and reacted negatively, the author is now considering making her contribute more.

First, I need to break down the key points. The author pays all the rent and bills, which might be the current arrangement. The girlfriend's part-time job might mean she can't contribute much financially, but the author is upset about her attitude when she had to pay for the takeout. The author feels it's about principle, wanting her to carry her weight even though she can't pay much. The question is whether the author is in the wrong by making her start paying some bills over this one incident.

I should consider both sides. On one hand, the author has been covering all expenses, which is fair if that's the agreed-upon arrangement. The incident might have been a minor one, just a $40 takeout, but the author is now upset because of the girlfriend's reaction. The author might be feeling that this incident shows the girlfriend isn't contributing, even if financially, and wants to set a new precedent. On the other hand, the girlfriend's reaction might be due to feeling taken advantage of or stressed about her limited income. The author's decision to change the financial arrangement based on a single incident could be seen as reactive and possibly unfair, especially if there was no prior discussion about splitting expenses.

Also, relationships often require communication and negotiation. If the author never discussed splitting bills before, maybe the girlfriend didn't realize the expectation. The author's frustration is understandable, but making her pay after this one incident without prior discussion could be abrupt. The principle of fairness is important, but so is mutual understanding and flexibility, especially when considering someone's financial situation.

In terms of right or wrong, it's subjective. However, the author's approach might be flawed because changing the arrangement without talking about it first could lead to resentment. The key issue here is whether the author had a conversation about financial responsibilities before this incident. If not, then the author might be in the wrong for making a unilateral decision based on a minor event. The fact that the author is now considering it "just out of principal" suggests that it's more about perceived fairness than the girlfriend's actual ability to contribute, which could be unfair given her part-time job. Therefore, the author's approach could be seen as disproportionate to the situation.
